In 67 years, we produced over 17

In 2000, we began to develop the G650.
It was our first aircraft entirely

So, how do we make the process easier?
In two 2021, we started looking at
building a new app that would support
our sales design team. It would allow
our customers to block out the aircraft
and visualize material options quicker.
We introduced Cabin Creator in 2022,
built using Unreal Engine 4.27.
Cabin Creator 2 came with some caveats,
requiring hours of baking, limited
layouts, usually three to four layouts
per product, and limited material
styles. The 3D pipeline was much longer

prepare assets.
Then in 2024, we migrated to Unreal

amount of layouts and material
combinations.

it was actually getting to the point

whole process. And here's the worst

If we made one change, we had to do it

We were going to build it from the

this application. Um I don't think he

dream. So cabin creator 3.0. What what
were we wanting from this? Uh first off,
we wanted it to be data driven as per
this talk here. Um what does that mean?
We wanted data files to drive the 3D
functions in the UI. So rather than
having everything be hardcoded, uh we
wanted everything to uh come from these
data files. So one of the other things
we wanted from this is to be able to
manipulate the data outside of the
application. So uh rather than having to
repackage every time we made a minor
change, we want to be able to manipulate
some of that without repackaging
as that says. And then we also wanted to
make make it more modular. So rather
than having one blueprint, we wanted to
uh separate everything into kind of its
own constituent parts. All right. So
scalable UI, we also wanted this to be
scalable. So we wanted to be able to add
or remove buttons without uh you know
that cascading down and affecting
everything else. Uh we did not want this
to be hardcoded. We wanted to use as
much um datadriven workflow as possible
for it. We wanted it to be responsive.
So we wanted it to work on a lot of the
different screens. you know, we we do
have uh everything from a laptop up to a
um power wall. So, we wanted it to work
on all these different kinds of devices.
And uh then we wanted to use Unreal 5.
So, moving from Unreal 4 to Unreal 5 uh

increase our abilities to um you know,
not obviously have to light map bake.
Um, with those applications,
um, we actually because we had to
separate them out, each application was

the textures we're putting in there, all
the data, everything, uh, you know,
you're talking about eight times 20 GB.
So we wanted to do it all in one

one application to be less than 20

application, and it's actually under 10
gigabytes now. So it's quite an
impressive improvement.
Uh, and then also we wanted to be able
to add our layout and styling. As as

there's a lot of layout and styling and

such a massive project, we wanted to

whole project before building it. Um,
and uh, to understand the workload. So,
you know, if you go into a project and

depending on if you're bringing in

Security is a big deal with Gulfream. So
we knew we would probably need to talk

Um
so data driven. Why did we want this to
be data driven? Just to kind of uh re
resale all this. Uh we wanted to be able
to change the data without repackaging.
We wanted to it to be fairly easy to
make, you know, minor changes. Uh we
wanted to this was a big one. We wanted
to be able to hook data into other apps.
So if everything's stored internally in
Unreal, it's a lot harder to kind of
grab that data and use it within other
other applications. So uh we're kind of
trying to develop a whole architecture
here where we uh are able to use that
data and the save files and things like
that to hook into other applications
eventually as well. Uh I wanted the UI
to be scalable and the scene also to be
responsive and scalable.
So we looked at a couple of different
data types uh when we were building this
application. And so the first one was
the CSV files. Uh it was a you know
pretty easy beginning one just to start
with and think through. Uh there's
several pros to CSV files. Obviously
it's very widely supported. Um it's uh
you can manipulate it in Excel. So it
brings it right into data tables in uh
Excel. It's very human readable. It's
literally just strings separated by
commas. So you can read it very easily.
Uh but there's also several cons to CSV
files. Um they're one-dimensional. So
it's hard to get uh you know hierarchy
or or uh objects within objects within
objects. Um and then you're limited to
only numbers and strings for a variable.
Uh we also looked at strrus within
Unreal itself. So there's some obvious
pros with that. You can use any variable
type that Unreal has. Uh that's that's a
nice bonus. Uh also human readable. You
can just go into the strct and see uh
you know what you have in there.
However, the cons are again that it's
one-dimensional. While you could have
strrus within strrus, that's not always
a very good idea to, you know, you can
break your program pretty easily if you
make changes. Uh, and you can only
update and change this or really read it
very easily with an Unreal.
And then finally, JSON, which is what we
went with. Uh, so why did we choose
JSON? Here's some of the pros here. Uh,
it's multi-dimensional. So, because of
the use of objects, you can have objects
within objects within objects, you can
have lots of layers. Uh, it's widely
supported. So just about everybody
supports JSON. Uh human readable. So
even though there's a few uh tags for
coding and stuff like that, you can
still go into the file and read it very
easily. It's very simple, very easy to
use. Uh here's a big one for us. As I
mentioned, security um is a big deal at
Gulfream. Bringing in new even just data
types sometimes can be difficult. So we
are using it in a lot of applications at
GFream. So there's no worries about
that. And it's always it's already tied
into other Gulfream systems as well. Uh
again there's still cons though with uh
JSONs. It can be difficult to manage
larger JSON files because of the extra
coding that could probably be said of
any data type. However, um and then you
are still limited with varial type
variable types to strings and numbers.
So we we decided to kind of break up our
uh data files into two different types.
So we've got manifests and then we've
got schemes. And I'll kind of tell you a
little bit about what the difference is.
So manifests are not going to change at
runtime. Uh there's a limited number. So
we we sort of pre-program these
manifests ahead of time and anytime we
make changes then we'll push a new
manifest file. Uh this is what's going
to drive kind of what shows up in
general in the app. So any of the menu
options, buttons, things like that and
also what shows up in the actual scene
itself.
Schemes on the other hand do change at
runtime. uh there theoretically could be
an infinite number of them because the
customers actually uh can make or delete
uh different scheme files.
The they drive the currently selected
options and basically it's a save file.

So some of the issues we found on the

Now, depending on what you're uh using
this for, you know, when you go to like
for instance the outside of the
aircraft, it tends to not be quite as

sometimes um
